title: About Me
text: Did you ask who I am? Well, you’re about to find out.

title: Animation Movies Analysis
text: Academic performance is a multifaceted construct influenced by various factors that interact in complex ways. As a student myself, understanding the determinants of academic success is crucial for me to maintain my grades. Additionally, this helps to answer my curiosity on whether food is really key to excelling in studies.

title: Animation Movies Analysis
text: Academic performance is a multifaceted construct influenced by various factors that interact in complex ways. As a student myself, understanding the determinants of academic success is crucial for me to maintain my grades. Additionally, this helps to answer my curiosity on whether food is really key to excelling in studies.

title: Animation Movies Analysis
text:
Aim
My analysis of study performance aims to delve into the diverse factors that impact study performance, shedding light on both individual and situational variables that contribute to academic outcomes.

title: Animation Movies Analysis
text:
About Data Set
The data set that I am using for my analysis is from Kaggle by BHAVIK JIKADARA titled: “Student Study Performance”. The data-set contains marks secured by students in different subjects namely, Mathematics, Writing, and Reading, the students’ parents educational background, their test preparation course completion status, etc. The following is a glimpse of the data set:

title: About Me
text:
Self Introduction
Greetings! I’m Jacqueline Bernice Howard, a student at NUS majoring in Communications and New Media (I love CNM!). Despite my name sounding angmoh, I am not. As a matter of fact, I am a proud Indonesian who was born and raised in that country. Here’s a proof that I am not angmoh:





As I approach my 20th birthday later this year, I find myself reminiscing about my experiences over the last two decades. Having been a student nearly my entire life, I often wonder if my academic performance is affected by my gender or my parents’ education. In addition, many people have told me that if I prepared for tests, I would definitely ace them. However, I had experienced the opposite in the past where I thought I had prepared myself well but I ended up getting average grades. Hence, I decided to test whether a student’s grade is truly affected by test preparation, whether a student’s grade is affected by gender and parents’ educational background, and whether having lunch before tests matters.

title: My Data Story

[1] "gender"                      "parental_level_of_education"
[3] "lunch"                       "test_preparation_course"    
[5] "math_score"                  "reading_score"              
[7] "writing_score"               "average_score"              



Gender and Average Score: Is there any difference between female and male?


Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.3.2






The median score appears to be higher for females than for males. However, the spread of scores appears to be larger for males than for females. One of the reasons for this might be that there are other factors besides gender that influence the test score, and these factors might have a larger effect on males than females.



    Two Sample t-test

data:  study$average_score by study$gender
t = 4.19, df = 998, p-value = 3.036e-05
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group female and group male is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 1.993744 5.506248
sample estimates:
mean in group female   mean in group male 
             69.5695              65.8195 



But, how about within each subject (Math, Writing, Reading)?












Interestingly, when both genders are plotted against all three subjects, males appear to score higher in all subjects. There could be a number of reasons for this. For example, males might be more interested in certain subjects than females, or they might have had better teachers in those subjects.

title: Data Insights
text:
The variables in the “study_performance” data-set are as the following:

“gender” to indicate sex of students (female or male)
“race_ethnicity” to indicate which racial group the students belong to
“parental_level_of_education” to indicate students’ parents final education (bachelor’s degree, some college, master’s degree, associate’s degree, high school)
“lunch” to indicate whether students had their lunch before test (standard or free/reduced)
“test_preparation_course” to indicate whether students had completed their test preparation or not
“math_score” to indicate students’ score in Maths
“reading_score” to indicate students’ score in Reading
“writing_score” to indicate students’ score in Writing
“average_score” to indicate students’ average score from all tests combined

title: Data Insights
text:
Comparing Score by Gender
By comparing scores, we can identify any gaps in academic performance between genders. This analysis can reveal whether one gender consistently outperforms the other in certain subjects or overall academic achievement.
As seen from the plot…


Comparing Score by Gender, on average
As seen on the plot below, the median score appears to be higher for females than for males. However, the spread of scores appears to be larger for males than for females.







Comparing Score by Gender, in each subjects (Math, Writing, Reading)
This is also evident when comparing both genders’ scores in respective subjects.

title: Data Insights
section: Parent’s Educational Background and Child’s Academic Performance: Are they related?
text:
Parent’s Educational Background and Child’s Academic Performance: Are they related?
Upon looking at scores comparison across both genders which shows that females tend to score higher than males, it comes to the question whether other factors such as students’ parents educational background influence the students or children’s academic performances.
According to the plot below, there is a positive correlation between parents’ educational background and students’ academic performances (average score). This means that students of parents with higher levels of education tend to score higher on average on academic tests.
However, it is important to note that correlation does not equal causation. There may be other factors that influence both parental education and child average scores. For example, children of wealthier families may be more likely to have parents with higher levels of education and also have access to better schools and resources.

title: Data Insights
text:
Pre-test Lunch: Does it matter?
It is vital to properly nourish the body if you want to succeed in your studies, according to… Here, I will test whether students who ate standard or normal lunch do better on tests than those who didn’t eat lunch or had reduced portions.





Based on the violin plot above, it appears that students with standard lunch has a higher median score than students who had free/reduced lunch. The violin for “standard lunch” is also narrower than the violin for “free/reduced lunch”, which means the scores in the “standard lunch” group are more clustered together. The tails of the violins are about the same length, which means the spread of the data is similar in both groups. In short, the violin plot suggests students who had standard lunch might score higher than those with reduced or no lunch.

title: Data Insights
section: Do well-prepared students always score higher than those who didn’t prepare?
text:
Do well-prepared students always score higher than those who didn’t prepare?





The group labeled “Completed” appears to have a higher average test score than the group labeled “None”. The average score for the “Completed” group is around 75, while the average score for the “None” group is closer to 50. Overall, the graph suggests that taking a test preparation course may be associated with higher test scores.
